Dear Mr. Derscheid:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on May 14, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:

CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete,
sign, and date an updated treatment plan for
each resident at least once every 90-calendar
days following the initial treatment plan.
A total of four updated treatment plans were reviewed, three of which were
required to be in MISACWIS. One of four updated treatment plans was completed
after the 90-day required timeframe. Three of three updated treatment plans
required to be in MiSACWIS did not have the required signatures uploaded.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete,
sign, and date an initial treatment plan for each
resident within 30 calendar days of admission.
A total of four initial service plans were reviewed, two of which were required to
be in MISACWIS. Two of two initial service plans required to be in MiSACWIS did
not have the required signatures uploaded.
CCI Rule 400.4145 Periodic physical examinations.
• (1) An institution shall provide and document
periodic physical examination for each resident
as follows, unless greater frequency is medically
indicated:
• (b) At least once every 14 months for
youth 1 year of age or older.
Six of six files reviewed did not have the periodic physical examinations uploaded
to MISACWIS.
CCI Rule 400.4147 Dental care
• (1) A licensee shall provide for and document
dental examinations and treatment for each
resident 3 years of age and older.

Six of six of the files reviewed did not have the youth’s ongoing dental
documentation uploaded to MISACWIS.
CCI Rule 400.4108 Financing and audit
• (1) A licensee shall do all of the following:
• (a) Obtain an annual audit of all financial
accounts. Audits for nongovernmental
institutions shall be conducted by an
independent certified public accountant
who is not administratively related to the
agency.
The facilities third-party financial audit was not completed, and still under review
with the independent certified public accountant.

There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• 2023 Interim Inspection: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this
reporting period as a result of the Interim Inspection completed on May
30, 2023. This report included two violations for treatment plan
timeliness, and discharge reports not including a statement that the
discharge paperwork was reviewed with the resident, parent, and
responsible caseworker. The CAP included action steps for report
timeframes to be tracked by Pineview secretary, timeframe information
be placed on a google calendar, supervisor to review the reports weekly,

discharge documentation language updated to reflect a date and person
the discharge information was discussed with and provided to, and a
compliance review to occur quarterly for all action steps. The CAP was
implemented and successful as neither of these areas were citations
during this period under review.
• Special Investigation 2023C0000460 with CAP approval date of
8/1/2023 was a result of a violation for Intervention standards and
prohibitions. The agency reviewed the incident with the staff involved,
retrained all staff members on the approved SCM restraint techniques,
and updated the emergency staffing options for additional staff to be
available to switch out with staff in volatile situations. The facility
completed all actions steps of the CAP on 2/1/2024.
• Special Investigation 2023C0000470 with CAP approval date of 8/18/23
was a result of a violation for Emergency restraint and Health status
assessment, notification; debriefing; reporting. The agency retrained
staff on approved SCM restraint techniques and releases, and training
on incident reporting and timeliness. The facility completed all action
steps of the CAP on 2/2/2024.
Financial Overview
The facility provided an internal budget however the third-party financial audit is
currently being completed therefore no financial review was able to be completed.
The facility will be expected to provide the audit as part of the corrective action
plan.
PREA compliance
Pineview completed their most recent PREA audit on April 18, 2022, and was
outlined in their 2023 Interim Inspection report. The agency will participate in
another PREA audit in 2024.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
since the last reporting period, the agency has changed programming and the
intake process. The change in the intake process created a decline in the census
for a few months however the agency was able to reset culture and programming
and increase the census with youth appropriate for their programs. This change in
programming and reestablishing of the culture has boosted staff morale and
reduced staff turnover. The facility continues to focus on report timeliness and
enhance staff trainings related to proper intervention techniques.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were completed during the inspection. The staff all report feeling
supported by administration and enjoying the new programming. The staff report
they now feel like they are able to build relationships with the youth and work on
treatment goals instead of just dealing with crisis management.

Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. Youth reported feeling
safe and having all their needs met. The youth all were able to identify someone
they felt comfortable talking to at the facility. The youth did not have any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on May 14, 2024.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
